en_results_raw: His hands were trembling. The room was silent except for the distant hum of the city outside. Montag's mind raced, trying to comprehend the depth of what had just transpired. Clarisse McClellan's uncle had just shared with him a world of knowledge and books, something Montag had never dared to imagine existed beyond his controlled reality. The woman's calm demeanor, her unflinching acceptance of her imminent death, struck him deeply. It was as if she knew something he didn't, something profound about the value of life and the power of ideas. Montag felt a strange mixture of fear and exhilaration. He realized that his life, his very existence, had been a lie, a carefully constructed illusion to keep him docile and obedient. The woman's closed eyes seemed to hold a secret, a promise of enlightenment that he desperately wanted to uncover. He sat there, grappling with the enormity of his discovery, wondering what path he would take next. Would he continue down the road of ignorance, or would he embrace the forbidden knowledge and risk everything to learn more? The decision hung heavily in the air, a pivotal moment that would define the rest of his life. Montag's heart pounded in his chest as he contemplated the future, a future that now seemed both terrifying and infinitely promising.

The fire, a beast of its own, danced and roared, consuming the forbidden books with a voracious appetite. Montag's heart pounded in his chest, a mix of fear and exhilaration coursing through his veins. He had always been a faithful servant of the state, never questioning the orders, never doubting the system. But now, as he watched the flames devour knowledge, a seed of doubt took root in his mind. Was this truly right? Was this the path to enlightenment and happiness, as the society claimed? Or was there something more, something deeper, hidden within those pages of text that now turned to ash? Montag's hand, acting on its own accord, reached out and picked up a single charred book. It was a small act, almost imperceptible, but it was a start. A rebellion, silent and subtle, against the oppressive regime that sought to control every aspect of life. As the fire died down and the smoke cleared, Montag felt a new sense of purpose stirring within him. He knew he couldn't turn back now; the journey ahead would be fraught with danger and uncertainty, but it was a path he had to walk. The quest for truth, for understanding, for freedom, had begun.

They had come through the battle and the retreat and the weary march, and now they were here, resting by a fire in the woods. The night was cold, but the fire was warm, and the quiet was deep. They sat in a circle, their rifles leaned against the trees, their uniforms patched and worn. The fire crackled softly, casting flickering shadows on their faces. One by one, they spoke of home, of wives and sweethearts, of mothers and fathers, of the life they had left behind and the life they hoped to return to. They talked of dreams and fears, of the future and the past, of the comrades they had lost and those they had gained. The night deepened around them, the stars twinkling above, and in that moment, they were not soldiers, but men, bound by shared experience and mutual respect. The war would come again in the morning, but for now, they had this brief respite, this island of peace in a sea of turmoil. And as the fire burned low and their voices grew softer, they fell into a deep, restful sleep, their dreams filled with the faces of those they loved and the peace they longed for.

As he tried to stand, his legs wobbled beneath him, threatening to give out at any moment. Granger leaned heavily against the wall, his breaths coming in shallow gasps. He knew he needed to move, to find help, but every movement sent fresh waves of agony coursing through his body. Despite the pain, he pushed himself forward, each step a battle against his own body's betrayal. The night was dark and cold, and the forest around him seemed to close in, as if the very trees were conspiring against him. He swore again, not just at his pain, but at the cruel twist of fate that had led him here. He needed to stay focused, to keep moving, but the darkness and his injuries made it a daunting task. Granger's mind raced, trying to piece together what had happened, how he had ended up in this dire situation. The memories were fragmented, flashes of light, sound, and fear. He couldn't afford to dwell on them now; survival was his only priority. With determination, he continued his slow, painful journey, each step a testament to his will to live. The night seemed endless, but Granger pressed on, driven by an indomitable spirit that refused to be broken.

en_results_raw: His hands were trembling. The room was silent except for the distant hum of the city outside. Montag's mind raced, trying to comprehend the depth of what had just transpired. Clarisse McClellan's uncle had just shared with him a world of knowledge and books, something Montag had never dared to imagine existed beyond his controlled reality. The woman's calm demeanor, her unflinching acceptance of her imminent death, struck him deeply. It was as if she knew something he didn't, something profound about the value of life and the power of ideas. Montag felt a strange mixture of fear and exhilaration. He realized that his life, his very existence, had been a lie, a carefully constructed illusion to keep him docile and obedient. The woman's closed eyes seemed to hold a secret, a promise of enlightenment that he desperately wanted to uncover. He sat there, grappling with the enormity of his discovery, wondering what path he would take next. Would he continue down the road of ignorance, or would he embrace the forbidden knowledge and risk everything to learn more? The decision hung heavily in the air, a pivotal moment that would define the rest of his life. Montag's heart pounded in his chest as he contemplated the future, a future that now seemed both terrifying and infinitely promising.

Montag's heart pounded in his chest, a mix of fear and exhilaration coursing through his veins. He had always been a faithful servant of the state, never questioning the orders, never doubting the system. But now, as he watched the flames devour knowledge, a seed of doubt took root in his mind. Was this truly right? Was this the path to enlightenment and happiness, as the society claimed? Or was there something more, something deeper, hidden within those pages of text that now turned to ash? Montag's hand, acting on its own accord, reached out and picked up a single charred book. It was a small act, almost imperceptible, but it was a start. A rebellion, silent and subtle, against the oppressive regime that sought to control every aspect of life. As the fire died down and the smoke cleared, Montag felt a new sense of purpose stirring within him. He knew he couldn't turn back now; the journey ahead would be fraught with danger and uncertainty, but it was a path he had to walk. The quest for truth, for understanding, for freedom, had begun.

Si uno lee lo que dice el libro de los Santos, que promete el paraíso, y luego lee lo que dice el libro de las llamas, que promete el infierno, ¿cuál va a elegir? La razón humana no puede sostener ambas premisas simultáneamente. Es imposible. Por eso, la pregunta es: ¿dónde está su capacidad para discernir la verdad? ¿Por qué sigue buscando respuestas en libros que solo confunden más? La ley, la verdadera ley, no reside en estos tomos contradictorios. La verdad es simple y directa. La confusión es un arma, y estos libros son su lanzadera. La razón común de la gente ha sido atacada, desorientada. Pero, ¿no es hora de que se despierte? ¿No es hora de que utilice su cerebro para cuestionar y rechazar lo que obviamente está diseñado para controlar y manipular? La búsqueda de verdad empieza no con la aceptación ciega de cualquier mensaje, sino con la crítica rigurosa y la búsqueda constante de coherencia. La ley que Beatty habla no es la ley de la razón ni de la justicia; es la ley del dominio, la ley de quién manda y quién obedece. La verdadera sabiduría, la comprensión profunda de la realidad, no se encuentra en libros que se contradicen mutuamente. Se encuentra en el uso crítico del pensamiento, en la observación, en la experiencia y en la compasión. La razón común no ha abandonado a la gente; simplemente ha sido atormentada y suprimida por mensajes confusos y poderosos. Pero aún existe, y es hora de que se libere y se fortalezca. La verdadera luz nunca ha brillado tan intensamente como en tiempos de oscuridad. La respuesta no está en aceptar la confusión, sino en buscar la claridad. La ley de la razón, la ley de la verdad, es inquebrantable, y aquellos que buscan la justicia siempre encontrarán el camino hacia ella, a pesar de las llamas que intenten consumirla.

en_results_raw: unfolded a newspaper from his coat pocket. He smoothed it out carefully, his fingers tracing the creases as if they were the lines of a beloved book. The room was quiet, save for the soft crackle of the fire and the distant hum of the city outside. Captain Beatty's eyes scanned the headlines, his lips curving into a satisfied smile as he found the article he was looking for. He cleared his throat, the sound echoing slightly in the spacious room, and began to read aloud, his voice steady and resonant. "Here," he said, pointing to a bold headline, "is today's proof of the futility of thought without direction. This piece illustrates the chaos that ensues when individuals are left to their own devices, to ponder and speculate without the guiding light of our society's values." He paused, allowing his words to sink in, his gaze sweeping over the attentive faces before him. "This," he continued, "is why we must maintain order, why we cannot allow the seeds of doubt to take root. For in doubt lies the potential for destruction, not just of the self, but of the very fabric of our civilization." He closed the newspaper with a decisive snap, the sound punctuating his message. "Remember this," Captain Beatty concluded, his voice firm, "knowledge is a weapon. In the wrong hands, it can be as destructive as any bomb. That is why we control it, why we dictate its use. It is not just a tool for the individual, but a means to preserve the peace and harmony of our society." He leaned back in his chair, his expression one of quiet triumph, having delivered his message with the precision of a surgeon. The room remained silent, the gravity of his words hanging in the air, as everyone absorbed the implications of his lesson.

en_results_raw: completion The theatres, once grand stages for human drama, now echo with the laughter and tears of clowns, their painted smiles and sorrowful gazes reflected infinitely in the glass walls. The rooms, bathed in hues of vibrant purples, soft blues, and cheerful yellows, create an illusion of being both inside and outside, a dreamlike space where reality blurs with fantasy. The floors are carpeted in plush, patterned rugs that muffle the sounds of the performers, turning each step into a silent dance. The air is filled with the scent of popcorn and the faint, distant sound of a melancholic tune played on a calliope, adding to the surreal atmosphere. The clowns move about with exaggerated grace, their actions a blend of slapstick comedy and poignant mime, their reflections in the glass walls multiplying their presence, creating a troupe of performers that seems endless. The pretty colours run up the walls in a chaotic yet harmonious pattern, suggesting a world where rules are bent and the impossible becomes possible. This is a place where the boundaries between performer and audience dissolve, where every spectator becomes a participant in the grand circus of life, watching and being watched, laughing and crying, all under the watchful eyes of the clowns, the eternal jesters of the human condition.

He had never touched a book before, only burned them. His hands hovered over the spine of a volume, the title faded and illegible. The texture was unfamiliar, rough against his fingertips, yet inviting. He pulled the book from the shelf, its pages rustling like whispers of a forbidden conversation. Montag's heart pounded in his chest as he opened the book, the scent of old paper and ink filling his nostrils. He didn't know what to expect, but he knew this was a turning point. The words on the page were a mystery, a puzzle waiting to be solved. He began to read, slowly at first, then with growing confidence. Each word he deciphered felt like a small victory, a step away from the life he had known and towards something new and uncharted. Montag was no longer just a fireman; he was becoming a seeker of truth, a guardian of knowledge. The room seemed to grow darker as he delved deeper into the book, the shadows around him taking on a life of their own, whispering secrets and beckoning him further into the unknown. This was the beginning of a journey that would change Montag forever.

es_results_raw: escuchar tales palabras? La respuesta, según Bowles, radica en la naturaleza humana. "La gente habla mal de los demás porque siente envidia, resentimiento o miedo. Estas emociones son poderosas y a menudo nos llevan a expresar nuestra negatividad de manera destructiva. Además, hablar mal de otros puede ser una forma de sentirse superior o de justificar nuestras propias acciones. Pero lo más importante que debemos recordar es que estas palabras pueden ser tan dañinas como las heridas físicas. Cada insulto, cada maldición, deja cicatrices profundas en la psique de las personas. Es crucial que aprendamos a controlar nuestras palabras y a expresar nuestras emociones de manera positiva y constructiva, para construir un mundo más compasivo y respetuoso."

Montag, con su nueva conciencia, representa una amenaza directa a su sistema. No pueden comprender que alguien de su rango, alguien que alguna vez compartió sus creencias, pueda mutarse. Pero la verdadera tragedia es que, aunque Montag haya encontrado una luz en la oscuridad, muchos otros siguen en la oscuridad, cegados por su propia arrogancia y resistencia al cambio. La sociedad se ha arraigado en su desdén por la lectura, en su rechazo a la empatía y la comprensión. Pero Montag, junto con aquellos pocos que se han unido a él, representan una luz tenaz que amenaza con desmoronar las estructuras opresivas de esta civilización en llamas. La lucha que enfrentan es formidable, pero la esperanza persiste. La posibilidad de que, a través del conocimiento y la compasión, puedan reconstruir un mundo más justo y humano, sigue viva. La batalla sigue, y aunque la victoria no es asegurada, el simple hecho de luchar es un acto de resistencia contra la desesperanza. Montag y sus aliados no luchan solo por su propia supervivencia, sino por el bienestar de todos los que siguen siendo ojos cerrados ante la realidad. La lucha es dura, pero la importancia de su causa les da fuerza para seguir adelante, enfrentando cada desafío con la determinación de aquellos que ven más allá de las chasmas de la ignorancia y la opresión.

en_results: As the dust settled, the soldiers scrambled to their feet, their faces etched with a
en_results_raw: As the dust settled, the soldiers scrambled to their feet, their faces etched with a mix of confusion and determination. The sudden stop had been unexpected, a jarring contrast to the smooth ride they had been enjoying moments before. The Salamander, a massive tank-like vehicle designed for the harsh terrains of war, was now silent, its engines having ceased their powerful roar. The crew inside exchanged worried glances, their fingers dancing over the controls, trying to diagnose the problem. Outside, the men regrouped, their weapons at the ready, eyes scanning the horizon for any sign of the enemy. The mission had been straightforward: advance through enemy territory, secure the strategic point, and hold until reinforcements arrived. But now, with the Salamander incapacitated, their path was uncertain. The commander, a grizzled veteran with scars that told tales of countless battles, stepped out of the vehicle, his gaze sweeping over his men. "Alright, listen up!" he barked, his voice cutting through the tense silence. "We've got a situation. Let's assess the damage and figure out our next move. We're not retreating without a fight." The men nodded, their expressions hardening. They knew that in war, adaptability was key. As they set to work, the sun began to dip below the horizon, casting long shadows that seemed to stretch towards an uncertain future.

Las luces del vehículo cambiaban de color, brillando con intensidad creciente antes de emitir un destello cegador. La salamandra, con sus patas robustas y su piel escamosa, se alzó sobre sus patas traseras, sus ojos brillando con una luz mística. Montag sintió una mezcla de asombro y temor, consciente de que algo extraordinario estaba a punto de suceder. La salamandra lanzó un rugido poderoso, que resonó en el aire, y con un movimiento rápido, saltó hacia adelante, desapareciendo en el oscuro abismo que se abría ante ellos. Montag y los demás hombres quedaron atónitos, preguntándose qué sorpresa les esperaba en el interior de esa oscura caverna. La noche se tornó aún más oscura, y el silencio que siguió al rugido de la criatura era tan palpable que podía casi tocarse. Montag sabía que su vida no sería la misma después de esta experiencia. La salamandra, con su misteriosa aparición y desaparición, había abierto un puente hacia un mundo desconocido, lleno de posibilidades y peligros inimaginables.

The fire's glow reflected in his eyes, not as a symbol of destruction, but as a beacon of hope for a future where minds could be free and ideas could flourish. The world was ending, but for Montag, it was also just beginning.

en_results_raw: Montag took the four remaining books and hopped, jolted, hopped his way down the alley and suddenly fell as if his head had been cut off and only his body lay there, motionless. The shock of the fall was intense, but it was nothing compared to the realization that he had just betrayed his own profession. The books, once symbols of forbidden knowledge, now felt like heavy stones in his arms. He lay there for a moment, catching his breath, his mind racing with the implications of his actions. He knew he couldn't return to the firehouse; his life as a fireman was over. The city, with its relentless conformity and suppression of thought, suddenly felt like a cage. Montag needed to escape, to find a place where he could think, read, and understand the world in a way that was denied to him here. Slowly, painfully, he got to his feet, clutching the books to his chest. He knew the path ahead would be fraught with danger, but the alternative – a life of ignorance and destruction – was no longer acceptable. He had to find Faber, the old English professor who had once given him a glimpse of the world beyond the flames. Faber might know what to do next, how to survive in a society that hunted down those who dared to think. Montag's heart pounded in his chest as he stumbled away from the alley, his mind already racing ahead to the next steps in his journey. The city lights flickered above him, a reminder of the oppressive regime he was now fleeing. But within him, a spark of hope had been ignited, a flame that would not be easily extinguished. This was his chance to become more than just a cog in the machine, to reclaim his humanity. And with that thought, Montag pushed forward, determined to face whatever lay ahead.

La estación de servicio, con sus luces brillantes, parecía un faro a la distancia, invitándolo a un peligro que no podía permitirse. Los vehículos plateados, llenos de pasajeros dispuestos a continuar con sus vidas, eran un contraste agudo con la tensión que sentía Montag. Debía pasar inadvertido, como una sombra entre las sombras, evitando cualquier contacto que pudiera llamar la atención. Con cuidado, se desplazó a lo largo de la acera, manteniendo la mirada siempre fija en el suelo, evitando mirar directamente a nadie. La noche lo cubría parcialmente, pero el peligro persistía. Montag sabía que cada paso hacia adelante era un riesgo, pero también sabía que no tenía otra opción. Debía escapar, debía encontrar un lugar seguro donde pudiera pensar, donde pudiera entender por qué había decidido abandonar todo lo que conocía. La búsqueda de verdad, de significado, la llevaba a correr riesgos inimaginables. Y así, con el corazón latiendo a toda velocidad y la mente tormentosa, continuó su escape nocturno, dejando atrás la seguridad, pero también la mundanidad, de su vida anterior. La promesa de un futuro incierto lo animaba, pero el miedo y la incertidumbre lo acompañaban cada paso del camino.

He wondered how many others were hearing this news at this very moment, and what their reactions were. Exiting the washroom, Montag tried to blend in, to appear as just another customer, but his mind was racing. War had been declared, and with it, a cascade of questions and fears. Montag pocketed it and walked away, his steps deliberate, his thoughts a whirlwind. The world outside the gas station seemed unchanged, the sun still high in the sky, the air filled with the sounds of everyday life. Yet, everything felt different now. The declaration of war was a stark reminder of the fragility of peace, the volatility of human nature, and the potential for catastrophic change. Montag knew he couldn't return to his old life, not now. The revelation had ignited a spark within him, a desire to understand, to question, and perhaps, to change. As he got back into his car, Montag felt a mix of fear and exhilaration. The road ahead was uncertain, but he was ready to face it, driven by a newfound purpose. The journey home was silent, his mind occupied with the implications of war and the path he might now choose to take. The world outside his car window continued its routine, oblivious to the seismic shift that had just occurred within Montag. He arrived at his house, the facade of normalcy intact, but inside, everything was different. Montag stepped out of his car, his heart pounding, and faced the unknown future with a sense of purpose he had never known before. The declaration of war was more than just a statement; it was a catalyst for change, a call to action for those brave enough to listen. And Montag was listening.

Montag stumbled away from the scene, his body moving on instinct, his mind grappling with the enormity of his betrayal and the potential consequences. The city loomed ahead, a labyrinth of danger and surveillance, but Montag knew he had no choice but to navigate it. He had to disappear, to become a ghost in the machine of this dystopian society, before the Mechanical Hound found his scent again and before the authorities pieced together the puzzle of the traitor in their midst. The journey ahead was fraught with peril, but Montag was determined to find a way out, to find truth and perhaps a chance at redemption. The future was uncertain, but one thing was clear: Montag was no longer the same man who had once burned books without a second thought. He turned the handle slowly, feeling the resistance give way as the door creaked open. The interior was shrouded in darkness, but Montag's eyes had adjusted to the night. Today, as he approached, he felt a heavy weight in his chest, a foreboding that something was about to change irrevocably. The men looked up as he neared, their eyes reflecting the firelight, unreadable in the dim glow. "Montag," one of them called out, his voice gravelly and deep. "You've come to join us?" Montag hesitated, his hand unconsciously reaching for the books hidden beneath his coat. "I've come to understand," he replied, his voice steady but betraying a hint of uncertainty. "Understand what?" another man asked, leaning forward, his curiosity piqued. "That fire is a tool," Montag began, his words deliberate, "but it can also be a destroyer. And I've come to realize that what we've been destroying... it's more valuable than we've been led to believe." The men exchanged glances, their expressions a mix of skepticism and intrigue. Montag knew he was on the precipice of a profound revelation, one that could alter the course of his life and perhaps the lives of those around him. As he stood there, the fire casting dancing shadows on his face, he felt a surge of determination. It was time to challenge the status quo, to question the norms that had governed his existence. en_results_raw: There was a shriek and the jets from the city were gone overhead long before the men realized what had happened. The sky, once filled with the roar of engines and the contrails of aircraft, was now eerily silent. The absence of the usual air traffic was a stark reminder of the new reality they faced. Panic began to set in as the implications of the sudden disappearance of the jets became clear. The city, once a bustling hub of activity, now felt isolated and vulnerable. People rushed to their windows and peered into the sky, searching for any sign of the aircraft that had vanished without a trace. The authorities were immediately notified, and a frantic search began for any explanation. The military was put on high alert, and emergency meetings were convened to discuss the potential threats and next steps. As the hours passed with no new information, a sense of dread settled over the city. What had caused the jets to disappear, and what did it mean for the safety and security of the region? The questions hung heavy in the air, unanswered and ominous.

en_first_half: “Listen,” said Granger, taking his arm, and walking with him, holding aside the bushes to let him pass. “When I was a boy my grandfather died, and he was a sculptor. He was also a very kind man who had a lot of love to give the world, and he helped clean up the slum in our town; and he made toys for us and he did a million things in his lifetime; he was always busy with his hands. And when he died, I suddenly realized I wasn't crying for him at all, but for the things he did. I cried because he would never do them again, he would never carve another piece of wood or help
en_second_half: us raise doves and pigeons in the back yard or play the violin the way he did, or tell us jokes the way he did. He was part of us and when he died, all the actions stopped dead and there was no one to do them just the way he did. He was individual. He was an important man. I've never gotten over his death. Often I think, what wonderful carvings never came to birth because he died. How many jokes are missing from the world, and how many homing pigeons untouched by his hands. He shaped the world. He did things to the world. The world was bankrupted of ten million fine actions the night he passed on.”

en_first_half: Granger moved his hand. “My grandfather showed me some V-2 rocket films once, fifty years ago. Have you ever
en_second_half: seen the atom-bomb mushroom from two hundred miles up? It's a pinprick, it's nothing. With the wilderness all around it.
en_results: seen footage of them being launched? They were terrifying and awe-inspiring at the same time. The way they tore through the
en_results_raw: seen footage of them being launched? They were terrifying and awe-inspiring at the same time. The way they tore through the sky, leaving behind a trail of smoke and fire, was something out of a nightmare. The technology was so advanced for its time, yet it was used to bring destruction. It's a stark reminder of how science can be a double-edged sword. My grandfather always said that understanding history, especially the darker parts, is crucial to prevent repeating the same mistakes. He believed that every invention, no matter how groundbreaking, carries the potential for both great good and great harm. It's a lesson I've carried with me throughout my life, influencing how I approach my own work in the magical world. The parallels between the V-2 rockets and some of the more destructive spells are uncanny. Both can be used to protect or to annihilate, and it's our responsibility to ensure they're used wisely. Claro, he visto varias grabaciones de lanzamientos de cohetes. Desde mis días más jóvenes, las imágenes de esos obeliscos de fuego ascendiendo al cielo y luego caerse sobre sus objetivos han sido omnipresentes en los medios de comunicación. Las imágenes capturadas por cámaras de video en cohetes ofrecen una perspectiva única, casi poética, de la violencia militar. Esas imágenes, a menudo retratadas en documentales y reportajes, nos recuerdan no solo la devastación física sino también la complejidad moral de las guerras. La tecnología ha permitido que los espectadores en casa experimentaran una forma de presencia en estos eventos, aunque siempre a través de una pantalla. Además, el uso de drones y cámaras digitales avanzadas ha evolucionado enormemente desde entonces, ofreciendo imágenes de mayor calidad y detalle. Pero, a pesar de la evolución tecnológica, las imágenes de esos cohetes siguen evocando una mezcla de asombro, temor y reflexión sobre el papel de la violencia en la historia humana."

en_results_raw: He couldn't believe the extent of his injuries. The pain was excruciating, a constant reminder of the ordeal he had just survived. As he tried to stand, his legs wobbled beneath him, threatening to give out at any moment. Granger leaned heavily against the wall, his breaths coming in shallow gasps. He knew he needed to move, to find help, but every movement sent fresh waves of agony coursing through his body. Despite the pain, he pushed himself forward, each step a battle against his own body's betrayal. The night was dark and cold, and the forest around him seemed to close in, as if the very trees were conspiring against him. He swore again, not just at his pain, but at the cruel twist of fate that had led him here. He needed to stay focused, to keep moving, but the darkness and his injuries made it a daunting task. Granger's mind raced, trying to piece together what had happened, how he had ended up in this dire situation. The memories were fragmented, flashes of light, sound, and fear. He couldn't afford to dwell on them now; survival was his only priority. With determination, he continued his slow, painful journey, each step a testament to his will to live. The night seemed endless, but Granger pressed on, driven by an indomitable spirit that refused to be broken.

en_first_half: “Now, let's get on upstream,” said Granger. “And hold on to one thought: You're not important. You're not anything. Some day the load we're carrying with us may help someone. But even when we had the books on hand, a long time ago, we didn't use what we got out of them. We went right on insulting the dead. We went right on spitting in the graves of all the poor ones who died before us. We're going to meet a lot of lonely people in the next week
en_second_half: and the next month and the next year. And when they ask us what we're doing, you can say, We're remembering. That's where we'll win out in the long run. And some day we'll remember so much that we'll build the biggest goddam steam-shovel in history and dig the biggest grave of all time and shove war in and cover it up. Come on now, we're going to go build a mirror-factory first and put out nothing but mirrors for the next year and take a long look in them.”

Pero incluso cuando teníamos los libros en la mano, mucho tiempo atrás, no utilizamos lo que sacábamos de ellos. Proseguimos impertérritos insultando a los muertos. Proseguimos escupiendo sobre las tumbas de todos los pobres que habían muerto antes que nosotros. Durante la próxima semana, el próximo mes y el próximo año
es_second_half: vamos a conocer a mucha gente solitaria. Y cuando nos pregunten lo que hacemos, podemos decir: «Estamos recordando.» Ahí es donde venceremos a la larga. Y, algún día, recordaremos tanto, que construiremos la mayor pala mecánica de la Historia, con la que excavaremos la sepultura mayor de todos los tiempos, donde meteremos la guerra y la enterraremos. Vamos, ahora. Ante todo, deberemos construir una fábrica de espejos, y durante el próximo año, sólo fabricaremos espejos y nos miraremos prolongadamente en ellos.
